Title.evidence: Immediate Lymphatic Reconstruction for Reducing Breast Cancer-Related Lymphedema: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: women undergoing ALND for breast cancer were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: women undergoing ALND for breast cancer

Intervention.evidence: ILR involved lymphatic anastomosis to a regional vein using microsurgical techniques, while the control group had cut lymphatics ligated

Objective.evidence: investigates the efficacy of immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) in decreasing the incidence of breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of BCRL, defined as â‰¥10% relative volume change (RVC) from baseline in the affected extremity at 12, 18, or 24 months

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 144 patients were randomised, with 72 in each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: Preliminary analysis includes 99 patients with 12-month follow-up, 70 with 18-month follow-up, and 40 with 24-month follow-up

Result_Outcome.evidence: The cumulative incidence of BCRL was 9.5% in the ILR group and 32% in the control group (p=0.014)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported
